title: Does every line in a poem have to be capitalized? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. If you’re trying to write a traditional sonnet, you may want to—but even that is not necessary. Capitalizing the first word in every line of a poem was simply “standard practice”—convention and tradition—in poetry for a long time. It’s no longer considered necessary, and in fact, some people (and I’m one of them) argue that it’s unnecessary “ornamentation” and actually somewhat of a distraction. I think it helps separate sentences within a poem—and thus aids clarity of meaning— to just use standard punctuation, and only capitalize a word if it is the beginning of a sentence, rather than the beginning of a new line. And of course, if you are writing free verse, it is really counter-productive to capitalize the beginning of each line, especially since in free verse every line is not necessarily left-justified.

Dear Fabio, The answer is “no” because there are no rules in poetry. The fact that the first words of each line in a poem are usually capitalized is a convention, nothing more! The name e.e. cummings became famous in the English-speaking world precisely because he flouted the usual conventions of punctuation and grammar and was still able to write great poetry! Read his famous poem, “anyone lived in a pretty how town” online and you will see what I mean! Yours truly, Paul

Why does each new line of a poem start with a capital letter? Too bad he’s dead, or you could ask e e cummings. Why does a sentence start with a capital letter? Why does a proper noun start with a capital letter? Why do ALL nouns in German start with a capital letter? It’s convention. It’s the way we do things, and the way we were taught. No rhyme nor reason for it. We just do it — unless you’re e e cummings. (An example of e e’s poetry: somewhere i have never travelled, gladly beyondany experience,your eyes have their silence:in your most frail gesture are things which enclose me,or which i cannot touch because they are too near your slightest look easily will unclose methough i have closed myself as fingers,you open always petal by petal myself as Spring opens(touching skilfully,mysteriously)her first rose )

No. You are probably thinking of poetry in English as that convention is not followed in other languages. As stated, poets like e e cummings and many of the beats did not follow standard capitalization.
